Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: This morning, my daughter called, her voice bubbling with excitement. “Dad, we want you here tonight. Jacob’s graduation—he’s so proud. We’re all gathering for dinner. He wants you to say a few words.” My heart swelled; I’ve missed too many moments already. But as I hung up, the church secretary reminded me: tonight is the Vigil, the holiest night of the year. The sanctuary will be full, the community looking to me for guidance, for tradition, for comfort. I can already picture the pews packed, the candles flickering, the expectant faces. My grandson’s eyes, too, waiting for his grandfather’s blessing. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s joy, my congregation’s faith. Both need me, both expect me to be present, to give of myself fully. I pace the study, torn, the clock ticking toward evening, my heart pulled in two directions, unsure which call I can answer.
